05899483787942D2881A8943B12B9A4F.description: communicate their understanding of something (e.g., a familiar story, an experience, a song, a play) by representing their ideas and feelings through visual art

03D7D6582CAE4EACB4AF50B026A743DA.description: communicate their ideas through various visual art forms

E64DFD5DA4774F57A18CEA711BAB8068.description: respond to a variety of visual art forms (e.g., paintings, fabrics, sculptures, illustrations) from various cultures, including their own

19C23161C29D47D5B5ED7A93D6E5B57B.description: express their responses to visual art forms by making connections to their own experiences or by talking about the form

F69853D9A4764578B81D2FB6E7D6D2FD.description: express responses to a variety of visual art forms, including those from other cultures

04AA5B5AF8E745E58104085B324E0230.description: use problem-solving skills and their imagination to create visual art forms (e.g., choose materials to make a three-dimensional structure stable; choose an alternative way to fasten their materials if the first way is unsuccessful)

26E96430C0754F14A45E6AE5CDEEFB37.description: use problem-solving strategies when experimenting with the skills, materials, processes, and techniques used in visual arts both individually and with others

71154BB424B84DFDB9B735E62E32C0BF.description: explore different elements of design (e.g., colour, line, shape, texture, form) in visual arts

6D212EBC245E428499F3E5006BDECFAF.description: explore a variety of tools, materials, and processes of their own choice to create visual art forms in familiar and new ways (e.g., use natural and recycled materials at a learning centre)

CB1ACCBE3F21476D915419893B0E2AE8.description: demonstrate basic knowledge and skills gained through exposure to visual arts and activities in visual arts

F062014373F84FCAA84A02F5EE41CE80.description: demonstrate an awareness of personal interests and a sense of accomplishment in visual arts (e.g., contribute pages to a class book using their own ideas; offer to make a puppet for a play; create a sculpture from clay)

C5295DBD92474EF6AAF7C35879D01B17.description: demonstrate an awareness of themselves as artists through engaging in activities in visual arts

8BF43668B3BD4B4EBCAEE52BD340704B.description: communicate their ideas about something (e.g., a book, an experience, a painting) through sounds, rhythms, and music (e.g., create a song or a chant, create sound effects, use rhythms to enhance a song or poem)

F4BE1EA03BCF4FA1A494809D496D25B0.description: respond to music from various cultures, including their own (e.g., folk songs, Aboriginal chants, songs in different languages)

FE3CE5233C7E4EBAA06D3C83A486FC07.description: express their responses to music by moving, by making connections to their own experiences, or by talking about the musical form

3F66D08067CF48B5998C6849984CCF06.description: express responses to a variety of forms of music, including those from other cultures

20B54FC1456F402BBB895BD1269D9467.description: use problem-solving skills and their imagination to create music (e.g., experiment with different instruments to create a rhythm pattern to accompany a familiar song; contribute to making a variation on a familiar song with the class)

823D463686AD442994D439FD98D23181.description: use problem-solving strategies when experimenting with the skills, materials, processes, and techniques used in music both individually and with others

BC118F98D9184F81BAB085508C8994CD.description: explore different elements (e.g., beat, sound quality, speed, volume) of music (e.g., clap the beat of a song; tap their feet on carpet and then on tile, and compare the sounds; experiment with different instruments to accompany a song)

6F9AEF7BF48949B9A8AE49CED461F30B.description: demonstrate basic knowledge and skills gained through exposure to music and music activities

799B01F34ECF42528410B7CBACE4E43E.description: explore a variety of tools and materials of their own choice (e.g., spoons, castanets, rhythm sticks, music software) to create music in familiar and new ways

940E35EACDF7446594FAA22EEBFB94C6.description: demonstrate an awareness of personal interests and a sense of accomplishment in music (e.g., contribute their own ideas to a class song; create their own accompaniment to a song)

98FCFB90317C4811B9AC5CA27DAAF23E.description: demonstrate an awareness of themselves as musicians through engaging in music activities

81ED4E3EF25245A48373031B0F3F260D.description: express their responses to drama and dance (e.g., by moving, by making connections to their experiences with drama and dance, by talking about drama and dance)

CA12E59C61D44D1ABD492787F9AB4BF6.description: express responses to a variety of forms of drama and dance, including those from other cultures

1BD70E3863FE4BCD889006131BDF03DB.description: dramatize rhymes, stories, legends, and folk tales from various cultures, including their own (e.g., use actions, pictures, words, or puppets to tell a story at the dramatic play centre or at the block centre)

1B9B98C423C94B00821D9F85FFEB0018.description: use problem-solving skills and their imagination to create drama and dance (e.g., try out different voices for parts of a story or chant; find different ways to move to music, trying to connect the movement with the mood and speed of the music; create a sequence of movements)

E0C2D167180B4FC4851984369DF3033A.description: use problem-solving strategies when experimenting with the skills, materials, processes, and techniques used in drama and dance both individually and with others

422D170C1ACB4BB68DE3626886B9E2E6.description: explore different elements of drama (e.g., character, setting, dramatic structure) and dance (e.g., rhythm, space, shape)

F91B32726BFF40329B1D26D487536F19.description: demonstrate basic knowledge and skills gained through exposure to drama and dance and drama- and dance-related activities

39407A8DD21E48809188F957F5BA6EBF.description: explore a variety of tools and materials of their own choice (e.g., blocks, puppets, flashlights, streamers) to create drama and dance in familiar and new ways

0A7C66C93078431D8DD9F2125BC889BF.description: demonstrate an awareness of personal interests and a sense of accomplishment in drama and dance (e.g., contribute their own ideas to role playing; create their own actions to accompany a song or chant and/or follow actions created by a classmate)

268E947E50CA4992A03CADEF7ADB9B26.description: demonstrate an awareness of themselves as dramatic artists and dancers through engaging in activities in drama and dance

CCEE0C67F17C4CDF9279C257A4295405.description: use a functional grip in written communication to produce writing that they and others can read

7E0313BB99184E1489273F63317EE71F.description: demonstrate spatial awareness by doing activities that require the use of small muscles

EC4457995F5D44BDAC785A4E0490E7D7.description: begin to demonstrate control of small muscles in activities at a variety of learning centres (e.g., sand, water, visual arts centres) and when using a variety of materials or equipment (e.g., using salt trays, stringing beads, painting with paintbrushes, drawing, cutting paper, using a keyboard, using a mouse, writing with a crayon or pencil)

FF38F26DE79D4050BCF39D5B9AE09299.description: develop control of small muscles (fine-motor control) in a variety of contexts

54E973479FDE445FB6B37CF9399E2FF2.description: begin to demonstrate balance, whole-body and hand-eye coordination, and flexibility in movement (e.g., run, jump, climb, walk on the balance beam, play beach-ball tennis, catch a ball, play hopscotch)

AB5CEC3A28EE4341993266DEE4D1A714.description: begin to demonstrate control of large muscles with and without equipment (e.g., climb and balance on playground equipment; roll, throw, and catch a variety of balls; demonstrate balance and coordination during parachute games; hop, slide, or gallop in the gym or outdoors)

9DF9EE00E13043CBB52E720A6742F57F.description: demonstrate spatial awareness in activities that require the use of large muscles

12DBB1F572DD43438B3B3028FF3598C2.description: develop control of large muscles (gross-motor control) in a variety of contexts

3812826DF91344E5BC2BB0E51BA9529F.description: demonstrate strategies for engaging in cooperative play in a variety of games and activities

62D5FCC253E0479E8749B24B8B6AEC48.description: demonstrate persistence while engaged in activities that require the use of both large and small muscles (e.g., tossing and catching beanbags, skipping, lacing, drawing)

D3EFCA27951D4A5D9F6CA662310ABAB7.description: participate actively in creative movement and other daily physical activities (e.g., dance, games, outdoor play, fitness breaks)

A702C3E56D2A4047B68734CBB4C26DFD.description: participate willingly in a variety of activities that require the use of both large and small muscles

CCECCE36D71C4146A721711D76913C06.description: discuss what makes them happy and unhappy, and why

7328EAFB3C5E4625B823F88032C10178.description: discuss what action to take when they feel unsafe or uncomfortable, and when and how to seek assistance in unsafe situations (e.g., acting in response to inappropriate touching; seeking assistance from block parents, 911, playground monitors; identifying substances that are harmful to the body)

3AB21FE46C144679839605A83BC070AC.description: practise and discuss appropriate personal hygiene that promotes personal, family, and community health

9354EC22CE5A4270B129F6E42A320CDC.description: investigate the benefits of nutritious foods (e.g., nutritious snacks, healthy meals, foods from various cultures) and explore ways of ensuring healthy eating (e.g., buying nutritious food for meals, avoiding foods to which they are allergic)

FB56E64F887546F6B5435466D16B9B95.description: begin to demonstrate an understanding of the effects of healthy, active living on the mind and body (e.g., choose a balance of active and quiet activities throughout the day; remember to go to the snack centre; drink water when thirsty)

03A979354A3E4453ADF10642E932999D.description: demonstrate an awareness of health and safety practices for themselves and others and a basic awareness of their own well-being

08B1D0B693EA41868F0D07B95B388847.description: communicate and record results and findings after constructing things either individually or in groups (e.g., explain and/or show how they made their structure; record ideas using pictures, words, numbers on labels or in charts)

66152CB01C5549D290F5A590B6BAB8FE.description: select and use tools, equipment, and materials to construct things using the design process

F90664594D91472CACAE840A00B62D79.description: make predictions and observations throughout the design process

270E912C35A34167B4AF79E7F04A965E.description: state problems and pose questions as part of the design process

A34F6E750FDF4BFC93E201F7BC1D5AB5.description: identify practices that ensure their personal safety and the safety of others, and demonstrate an understanding of the importance of these practices

6EC3A6C5080042A9831224B2EF30384D.description: use technological problem-solving skills (questioning, planning, predicting, constructing, observing, communicating) in free exploration, focused exploration, and guided activity

3E0D8CDC8278489A8032DFCA2C227596.description: participate in environmentally friendly activities in the classroom and the schoolyard (e.g., plant and tend to plants; use local products for snack time)

FCEFC20DDB174E35A9D5828A7E88558D.description: identify ways in which they can care for and show respect for the environment (e.g., feeding the birds in winter; reusing and recycling; turning off unnecessary lights at home; walking to school instead of getting a ride)

EF1F28DCC41A43D4A3DC11B781AF9C9C.description: describe what would happen if something in the local environment changed (e.g., if trees in the park were cut down; if the pond dried up)

1409BBBEB8D64538924F9A30960CFD90.description: identify similarities and differences between local environments(e.g., between a park and a pond; between a schoolyard and a field)

BA79F96E043C4AAD857672840A4988AE.description: demonstrate an understanding of the natural world and the need to care for and respect the environment

2CA03839D28A4B7DB42DB4F0D559D453.description: communicate results and findings from individual and group investigations (e.g., explain and/or show how they made their structure; state simple conclusions from an experiment; record ideas using pictures, numbers, labels)

AA8CE112D18B49A69176026538B966C5.description: select and use materials to carry out their own explorations

BA737FA96E4D4E4C90D9E1D653FE89EA.description: make predictions and observations before and during investigations

452CE2624BB04873BA8AE22C631B10D1.description: state problems and pose questions before and during investigations

EDB9F89FD4524A6CB38402CF5172981B.description: conduct simple investigations through free exploration, focused exploration, and guided activity, using inquiry skills (questioning, planning, predicting, observing, communicating)

B4C44584A8E24B48BEBB70D134D4BC50.description: explore patterns in the natural and built environment (e.g., patterns in the design of buildings, in flowers, on animals' coats)

77C8310543C24C83B45D269C637C7D57.description: sort and classify groups of living and non-living things in their own way (e.g., using sorting tools such as hula hoops, sorting circles, paper plates, T-charts, Venn diagrams)

0B7F8D6C4D45497D9293FCE05A617BE5.description: ask questions about and describe some natural occurrences, using their own observations and representations (e.g., drawings, writing)

71CA6C8B7F2E4AE99F82E95EADD0DA7A.description: demonstrate an awareness of the natural and built environment through hands-on investigations, observations, questions, and representations of their findings

F70CFCD9638F419F841DBC9FB1557AC1.description: use mathematical language in informal discussions to describe probability

BA919E0B3B274B77AA9C2CEDF99CAA14.description: respond to and pose questions about data collection and graphs

8AE2B5B34DC0455BA6031639A3528E16.description: collect objects and data and make representations of their observations, using concrete graphs

F71D0D57C97149BABC351ADB1025053F.description: sort, classify, and compare objects and describe the attributes used

054ADA0CACEB411092F4ADA5169090B4.description: sort, classify, and display a variety of concrete objects, collect data, begin to read and describe displays of data, and begin to explore the concept of probability in everyday contexts

EAF063A1CE85495D97EB7C8D3F525020.description: identify and describe informally the repeating nature of patterns in everyday contexts (e.g., patterns in nature, clothing, floor tiles, literature, schedules), using oral expressions (e.g., "goes before", "goes after", "morning, noon, night", "the four seasons") and gestures (e.g., pointing, nodding)

66650ECC65EB48CDAA3168CCE329ECF8.description: identify, create, reproduce, and extend repeating patterns through investigation, using a variety of materials (e.g., attribute blocks, pattern blocks, a hundreds chart, toys, bottle tops, buttons, toothpicks) and actions (e.g., physical actions such as clapping, jumping, tapping)

11790F78C7F64B7AB0E43ED249660ECC.description: explore, recognize, describe, and create patterns, using a variety of materials in different contexts

0B5F118834054A469E7F18AE846599C5.description: demonstrate an understanding of basic spatial relationships and movements (e.g., use above/below, near/far, in/out; use these words while retelling a story)

05F5DAD6E97E4CCC86FB0B88323DCD13.description: investigate the relationship between two-dimensional shapes and three-dimensional figures in objects that they have made

ED9A6D3AE8A947B5BECB70E500B46E43.description: build three-dimensional structures using a variety of materials and begin to recognize the three-dimensional figures their structure contains

A3CAE0B56B75457791167A94B06D21BD.description: compose pictures, and build designs, shapes, and patterns, using two-dimensional shapes, and decompose two-dimensional shapes into smaller shapes, using various tools or strategies (e.g., sand at the sand table, stickers, geoboards, pattern blocks, a computer program)

A498B18DBC5D4739BDC8D3267A6E1E30.description: identify and describe, using common geometric terms, two-dimensional shapes (e.g., triangle) and three-dimensional figures (e.g., cone) through investigation with concrete materials

D6413A27F01F4AD88CD290FFBFB075FE.description: explore, sort, and compare traditional and non-traditional two-dimensional shapes and three-dimensional figures (e.g., compare equilateral triangles with triangles that are not equilateral; sort different sizes of boxes, attribute blocks, pattern blocks, a variety of triangles, shapes with three curved sides, objects that create an open shape with three lines)

FA90030463D744ABB0468A97A1F1C453.description: describe, sort, classify, build, and compare two-dimensional shapes and three-dimensional figures, and describe the location and movement of objects through investigation

31D3A67DF93F404AB659551975D8409C.description: demonstrate, through investigation, a beginning understanding of non-standard units that are the same type (e.g., straws, paper clips) but not always the same size

FB9F9F2C30EF47FF90D2D8E47D6A8D62.description: demonstrate, through investigation, an awareness of non-standard measuring devices (e.g., feet, hand spans, string, or cubes to measure length; hand claps to measure time; scoops of water or sand to measure capacity) and standard measuring devices (e.g., measuring cups at the water and sand centre, balance scales at the block centre) and strategies for using them (e.g., place common objects end to end to measure the length of the classroom; use cubes to plan the length of a road at the sand table or the block centre; use footsteps to measure the distance between the door and the sink)

EF52AEF44CBF42998B7AFDB1A9C2C5DC.description: compare and order two or more objects according to an appropriate measure (e.g., length, mass, area, temperature, capacity) and use measurement terms (e.g., hot/cold for temperature, small/medium/large for capacity, longer/shorter or thicker/thinner for length)

5CF5CBB7740F4F658629DDB2450914D7.description: measure and compare length, mass, capacity, area, and temperature of objects/materials, and the passage of time, using non-standard and standard units, through free exploration, focused exploration, and guided activity

CF2122A692674981B9C771CD11BDE4AD.description: investigate addition and subtraction in everyday activities through the use of manipulatives (e.g., interlocking cubes), visual models (e.g., a number line, tally marks, a hundreds carpet), or oral exploration (e.g., dramatizing of songs)

71A324C389F04B16A60760DD579FBED7.description: investigate and develop strategies for composing and decomposing quantities to 10 (e.g., use manipulatives or "shake and spill" activities)

8B299AB484D14C70A83E259432810781.description: explore different Canadian coins, using coin manipulatives (e.g., role-play the purchasing of items at the store at the dramatic play centre; determine which coins will purchase more â€“ a loonie or a quarter)

CDFD6C3EFF014288BA5C3E17A998BA16.description: use, read, and represent whole numbers to 10 in a variety of meaningful contexts (e.g., use a hundreds chart to read whole numbers; use magnetic and sandpaper numerals to represent the number of objects in a set; put the house number on a house built at the block centre; find and recognize numbers in the environment; write numerals on imaginary bills at the restaurant at the dramatic play centre)

C5FF7010374F45DA9D1997C43F5384D5.description: use ordinal numbers in a variety of everyday contexts (e.g., line up toys and manipulatives, and identify the first, second, and so on; after reading a book, respond to the ELâ€“K team's questions about who was the first or third person to come in the door)

6D56649104E64BE1BB48DD8053696D86.description: demonstrate an understanding of number relationships for numbers from 0 to 10, through investigation (e.g., show small quantities using fingers or manipulatives)

ABE8A6B1677C4F4CBADCA0CF7A146DC2.description: begin to use information to estimate the number in a small set (e.g., apply knowledge of quantity, use a common reference such as a five frame)

0001C86E41A74B48B9171A4FFD5468CF.description: recognize some quantities without having to count, using a variety of tools (e.g., dominoes, dot plates, dice, number of fingers) or strategies (e.g., composing or decomposing numbers, subitizing)

BC3912EBAF6D4C49801E8A691C944190.description: demonstrate understanding of the counting concepts of stable order (i.e., the concept that the counting sequence is always the same â€“ 1 is followed by 2, 2 by 3, and so on) and of order irrelevance (i.e., the concept that the number of objects in a set will be the same regardless of which object is used to begin the counting)

9328F7FB0DF34817A2511E98D3D61A64.description: begin to make use of one-to-one correspondence in counting objects and matching groups of objects (e.g., one napkin for each of the people at the table)

9FFAA0E4C2754BB0A88A3A456AAC07CB.description: investigate some concepts of quantity through identifying and comparing sets with more, fewer, or the same number of objects (e.g., find out which of two cups contains more or fewer beans, using counters; investigate the ideas of more, less, or the same, using five and ten frames; recognize that the last number counted represents the number of objects in the set [concept of cardinality])

042536E4BEB04A7891163B3A7B24049A.description: investigate (e.g., using a number line, a hundreds carpet, a board game with numbered squares) the idea that quantity is greater when counting forward and less when counting backwards

9933B685BCF9469299480D9A277C0417.description: demonstrate an understanding of numbers, using concrete materials to explore and investigate counting, quantity, and number relationships

19F6A1D282A94D6F86D2920327279E1A.description: communicate their ideas verbally and non-verbally about a variety of media materials (e.g., describe their feelings in response to seeing a DVD or a video; dramatize messages from a safety video or poster; paint pictures in response to an advertisement or CD)

E53AF5BD94C14F01AE781FAE458C0243.description: begin to respond critically to animated works (e.g., cartoons in which animals talk, movies in which animals go to school)

114F437C9F9D4CC2B2BEB1F2C0AF5763.description: demonstrate a beginning understanding and critical awareness of media texts

D849DEE7A8C64FDDB200B88EF45127D0.description: communicate ideas about personal experiences and/or familiar stories, and experiment with personal voice in their writing (e.g., make a story map of "The Three Little Pigs" and retell the story individually to an ELâ€“K team member during a writing conference)

0EFDCB00CC3741F2AF92C6D4A76086A8.description: experiment with a variety of simple writing forms for different purposes and in a variety of contexts

493E9D9ED4FA477C94848F32A9BB233F.description: begin to use classroom resources to support their writing (e.g., a classroom word wall that is made up of children's names, words from simple patterned texts, and words used repeatedly in shared or interactive writing experiences; signs or charts in the classroom; picture dictionaries; alphabet cards; books)

743AE8D3AA2140E080F96B5B7091BC50.description: write simple messages (e.g., a grocery list on unlined paper, a greeting card made on a computer; labels for a block or sand construction), using a combination of pictures, symbols, knowledge of the correspondence between letters and sounds (phonics), and familiar words

9FA25269380C404C8ED38AE90065C37C.description: demonstrate an awareness that writing can convey ideas or messages (e.g., ask the teacher to write out new words for them)

3BE1ABFDF1BF465291ED374DDB71B94B.description: demonstrate an interest in writing (e.g., choose a variety of writing materials, such as adhesive notes, labels, envelopes, coloured paper, markers, crayons, pencils) and choose to write in a variety of contexts (e.g., draw or record ideas at learning centres)

5E748E50ED444C52AD3DB52470DB501F.description: communicate in writing, using strategies that are appropriate for beginners

1B4957C96B22440FBE437B68C9DFF712.description: begin to use reading strategies to make sense of unfamiliar texts in print (e.g., use pictures; use knowledge of oral language structures, of a few high-frequency words, and/or of sound-symbol relationships)

4B6BC65A2BE14501874AA6C8E6545D92.description: use reading strategies that are appropriate for beginning readers in order to make sense of a variety of written materials

4C0BCB6B44F6419192271FAB90A842D2.description: retell information from non-fiction materials that have been read by and with the ELâ€“K team in a variety of contexts (e.g., read-alouds, shared reading experiences), using pictures and/or props

71B21F7E4186480AB490CD38F6330773.description: retell stories, in proper sequence, that have been read by and with the ELâ€“K team, using pictures in the book and/or props (e.g., use props such as finger puppets or flannel-board characters; use plastic models at the sand table to tell the story "The Gingerbread Man")

BD9D40D240E841BFB95BA140290786A7.description: demonstrate knowledge of most letters of the alphabet in different contexts (e.g., use a variety of capital and lower-case manipulative letters in letter play; identify letters by name on signs and labels in chart stories, in poems, in big books, on traffic signs; identify the sound that is represented by a letter; identify a word that begins with the letter)

FCADD00AF9A443618079ADEB4BB0695A.description: use illustrations to support comprehension of texts that are read by and with the ELâ€“K team

15A876B0B59644B99F2EAF9A5C1ADDCA.description: use prior knowledge to make connections (e.g., to new experiences, to other books, to events in the world) to help them understand a diverse range of materials read by and with the ELâ€“K team

A8DC7EBD6CA74750A4DD4C764B9F5286.description: make predictions regarding an unfamiliar text that is read by and with the ELâ€“K team, using prior experience, knowledge of familiar texts, and general knowledge of the world around them (e.g., use the cover pictures and/or title to determine the topic and/or text form)

02100121FDE848E9B4C780DC7315092A.description: respond to a variety of materials read aloud to them (e.g., paint, draw, or construct models of characters or settings)

9AD6011EAD3D467F8963CBB67A6895C7.description: demonstrate an awareness of basic book conventions and concepts of print when a text is read aloud or when they are beginning to read print (e.g., start at the beginning of the book; recognize that print uses letters, words, spaces between words, and sentences; understand that printed materials contain messages)

5C8D1D37272F49ADA917C91DAA24F644.description: identify personal preferences in reading materials (e.g., choose fiction and non-fiction books, magazines, posters, computerized interactive texts that they enjoy) in different contexts (e.g., ELâ€“K team read-alouds, shared experiences in reading books, independent reading time)

2F5EF6FD2E7F4BE1B7A090634339AA76.description: demonstrate an interest in reading (e.g., expect to find meaning in pictures and text; choose to look at reading materials; respond to texts read by an ELâ€“K team member; reread familiar text; confidently make attempts at reading)

D1F58C2B41B64D88A71ACC7592DF67E4.description: demonstrate understanding and critical awareness of a variety of written materials that are read by and with the ELâ€“K team

20FB18C9356648F4B09690661B941B89.description: demonstrate an awareness that words can rhyme, can begin or end with the same sound, and are composed of phonemes that can be manipulated to create new words

FEB894FBBEF04A3596C72A272478452D.description: orally retell simple events and simple familiar stories in proper sequence

5F46013C0EEA47A5A9F82F881D80DF95.description: describe personal experiences, using vocabulary and details appropriate to the situation

F4FFACF79C2643A2A01891B95DBE505B.description: ask questions for a variety of purposes (e.g., for direction, for assistance, for obtaining information, for clarification, for help in understanding something) and in different contexts (e.g., during discussions and conversations with peers and adults; before, during, and after read-aloud activities and shared reading; while making observations on a class walk; in small groups at learning centres)

18532FB401424F01BDBDB55A5DC347E6.description: use specialized vocabulary for a variety of purposes (e.g., terms for things they are building or equipment they are using)

7E19CBCF98EC4B349B6946405D28F4AA.description: use language to talk about their thinking, to reflect, and to solve problems

320B6A6B5DB8411CA5D5D26C37EFB9C3.description: use language in various contexts to connect new experiences with what they already know (e.g., contribute ideas orally during shared or interactive writing; contribute to conversations at learning centres; respond to teacher prompts)

52860F8244994FAD93A48418DD067A36.description: follow and provide one- and two-step directions in different contexts (e.g., in classroom routines; in music, drama, and dance activities; in outdoor play; in learning centres; in large-group activities)

1268EEAC0EB44CA5AD746577AB07B8A3.description: begin to use and interpret gestures, tone of voice, and other non-verbal means to communicate and respond (e.g., respond to non-verbal directions from the teacher; vary tone of voice when dramatizing; name feelings that are expressed in facial expressions in photos or illustrations; recognize when someone is upset)

F41D769A07CC47C59442445348A020FA.description: listen and respond to others for a variety of purposes (e.g., to exchange ideas, express feelings, offer opinions) and in a variety of contexts (e.g., after read-alouds and shared reading or writing activities; while solving a class math problem; in imaginary or exploratory play; at the learning centres; while engaged in games and outdoor play; while making scientific observations of creatures outdoors)

5E8F0D0CB25F480C982548DFA82B0328.description: explore sounds, rhythms, and language structures, with guidance and on their own

491FD5413BE2404988ED35F109042BC7.description: communicate by talking and by listening and speaking to others for a variety of purposes and in a variety of contexts

EF322C6CC2F641718E32A7794102E19C.description: develop an awareness of ways in which people adapt to the places in which they live (e.g., children in cities may live in high-rise buildings and use sidewalks and the subway; children in the country may take the bus to school)

0D9C470A143B43A6826983F68CDDCBE2.description: recognize places and buildings within their community, both natural and human-made, and talk about their functions (e.g., farm, church, hospital, mosque, sweat lodge, arena, mine, cave)

61A7683C9D784FFEB67EF323A738B1FD.description: recognize people in their community and talk about what they do (e.g., farmer, park ranger, police officer, nurse, Aboriginal healer, store clerk, engineer, baker)

52365F9279BB487584DE06F4D2A2624E.description: demonstrate an awareness of their surroundings

8C1739BF0B554CB5B7952D415EE0BF3B.description: interact cooperatively with others in classroom events and activities (e.g., offer and accept help in group situations, engage in small- and large-group games and activities, participate in democratic decision making)

01194EF268AD4FBCB621E2877151F42D.description: begin to demonstrate self-control (e.g., be aware of and label their own emotions, accept help to calm down, calm themselves down after being upset) and adapt behaviour to different contexts within the school environment (e.g., follow routines and rules in the classroom, gym, library, playground)

E705D2629C8B4238BD6CDD633AF3FE90.description: demonstrate self-motivation, initiative, and confidence in their approach to learning by selecting and completing learning tasks (e.g., choose learning centres independently, try something new, persevere with tasks)

93C5626D6CE74DC18C95D58054AE3F0C.description: demonstrate a willingness to try new activities (e.g., experiment with new materials/tools, try out activities in a different learning centre, select and persist with challenging activities, experiment with writing ) and to adapt to new situations (e.g., having visitors in the classroom, having a different teacher occasionally, going on a field trip, riding the school bus)

CE9C71AA2DEA4CC3BA6B44BDB6321C77.description: demonstrate self-reliance and a sense of responsibility (e.g., make choices and decisions on their own, take care of personal belongings, know when to seek assistance, know how to get materials they need)

377CABAF6D7A48728EB5A9B1474EF36F.description: demonstrate independence, self-regulation, and a willingness to take responsibility in learning and other activities

0891865EC53141A2B2D262494F4F98DC.description: express their thoughts (e.g., on a science discovery, on something they have made) and share experiences (e.g., experiences at home, cultural experiences)

271159CFAD144F6A89D4183140FAD778.description: identify and talk about their own interests and preferences

87F4B5E07A554E309A57AC6EFC60E66D.description: recognize personal interests, strengths, and accomplishments

0F5848BD966F496BAFCCB019FCF6ADA8.description: demonstrate a sense of identity and a positive self-image

9B9E4301151348C582ED42E0369D456D.description: talk about events or retell stories that reflect their own heritage and cultural background and the heritage and cultural backgrounds of others (e.g., traditions, birthdays, cultural events, myths, Canadian symbols, holidays)

46E6C4FD2EE046F7B20C81A419D955AA.description: demonstrate respect and consideration for individual differences and alternative points of view (e.g., help a friend who speaks another language, adapt behaviour to accommodate a classmate's ideas)

BAF02088052D403E89F4B1710F127074.description: develop empathy for others, and acknowledge and respond to each other's feelings (e.g., tell an adult when another child is hurt/sick/upset, role-play emotions with dolls and puppets)

8A9125D17274401295848F5B07DBCFC8.description: demonstrate a beginning understanding of the diversity in individuals, families, schools, and the wider community

0A4DC068C29C419799557000F68093E3.description: use a variety of simple strategies to solve social problems (e.g., seek assistance from the ELâ€“K team when needed, develop an awareness of honesty, talk to peers about possible solutions)

3E9DC3F2555045658238FD2398010B5D.description: demonstrate an ability to use problem-solving skills in a variety of social contexts

9D27B3FCFC294BFE8AA0DE651FB0D3EC.description: demonstrate an awareness of ways of making and keeping friends (e.g., sharing, listening, talking, helping; entering into play or joining a group with guidance from the ELâ€“K team)

D438BDB5B4FE44159165EDF3F7935D48.description: demonstrate the ability to take turns in activities and discussions (e.g., engage in play activities with others, listen to peers and adults)

AC74E76D34F34A3491254600330C43CD.description: act and talk with peers and adults by expressing and accepting positive messages (e.g., use an appropriatetone of voice and gestures, give compliments, give and accept constructive criticism)

41E4BE6AD75141C2AF4847F732DE63A6.description: identify and use social skills in play and other contexts
